summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the scheduling of Ghislaine Maxwell's arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the order addresses the possibility of conducting the proceedings remotely and includes a waiver form for Maxwell to sign if she chooses to waive her physical presence.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, for whom the court is scheduling an arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, who issued the scheduling order and will accept the waiver of presence.

connections.description: Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against defendant Maxwell.

events.title: Proposed Arraignment and Bail Hearing
events.description: The Government requested the court schedule Maxwell's arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing for the afternoon of this date.

events.title: Potential Remote Video Appearance
events.description: A potential time slot for Maxwell to appear by video from the Metropolitan Detention Center if proceedings are conducted remotely.

events.title: Potential Remote Video Appearance
events.description: A potential time slot during the morning for Maxwell to appear by video from the Metropolitan Detention Center if proceedings are conducted remotely.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court order is from July 6, 2020, and addresses the scheduling of initial proceedings for Ghislaine Maxwell's criminal case (20-CR-330).
Due to the COVID-19 public health crisis, the court is considering conducting the arraignment and bail hearing remotely, with Maxwell waiving her right to physical presence.

The document includes a detailed waiver form for a defendant to sign, giving up the right to be physically present at arraignment, bail hearings, and conferences, provided they can still consult privately with their attorney.
If proceeding remotely, Maxwell could be produced by video from the Metropolitan Detention Center only at specific times on July 9 or July 14, 2020.
The order instructs counsel to confer and propose a schedule by 9:00 p.m. on July 6, 2020, if they anticipate a remote proceeding.
